defs.docs: # pest. The Elegant Parser

attributes.value: / pest is a general purpose parser written in Rust with a focus on accessibility, correctness,
/ and performance. It uses parsing expression grammars (or [PEG]) as input, which are similar in
/ spirit to regular expressions, but which offer the enhanced expressivity needed to parse
/ The recommended way to start parsing with pest is to read the official [book].
/ * play with grammars and share them on our [fiddle]
/ * leave feedback, ask questions, or greet us on [Gitter]
/ The core of pest is the trait [`Parser`], which provides an interface to the parsing
/ The accompanying crate `pest_derive` can automatically generate a [`Parser`] from a PEG
/ grammar. Using `pest_derive` is highly encouraged, but it is also possible to implement
/ Grammar definitions reside in custom `.pest` files located in the crate `src` directory.
/ Parsers are automatically generated from these files using `#[derive(Parser)]` and a special
/ The syntax of `.pest` files is documented in the [`pest_derive` crate].
/ Grammars can also be inlined by using the `#[grammar_inline = "..."]` attribute.

defs.name: Pair
defs.docs: A matching pair of [`Token`]s and everything between them.

attributes.value: / A matching pair of [`Token`]s and everything between them.
/ A matching `Token` pair is formed by a `Token::Start` and a subsequent `Token::End` with the
/ same `Rule`, with the condition that all `Token`s between them can form such pairs as well.
/ This is similar to the [brace matching problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brace_matching) in

defs.name: set_call_limit
defs.docs:
Sets the maximum call limit for the parser state
 to prevent stack overflows or excessive execution times
 in some grammars.
 If set, the calls are tracked as a running total
 over all non-terminal rules that can nest closures
 (which are passed to transform the parser state).

attributes.value: / Sets the maximum call limit for the parser state
/ to prevent stack overflows or excessive execution times
/ If set, the calls are tracked as a running total
/ over all non-terminal rules that can nest closures
/ (which are passed to transform the parser state).
/ * `limit` - The maximum number of calls. If None,
/             the number of calls is unlimited.

defs.name: repeat
defs.value:
fn repeat<F>(Box<Self>, F) -> ParseResult<Box<Self>> where F: FnMut(Box<Self>)
-> ParseResult<Box<Self>>
defs.docs:
Repeatedly applies the transformation provided by `f` from the `Box<ParserState>`. Returns
 `Ok` with the updated `Box<ParserState>` returned by `f` wrapped up in an `Err`.

 `Ok` with the updated `Box<ParserState>` returned by `f` regardless of the `Result`.

 otherwise.

defs.name: lookahead
defs.value:
fn lookahead<F>(Box<Self>, bool, F) -> ParseResult<Box<Self>> where
F: FnOnce(Box<Self>) -> ParseResult<Box<Self>>
defs.docs:
Starts a lookahead transformation provided by `f` from the `Box<ParserState>`. It returns
 `Ok` with the current `Box<ParserState>` if `f` also returns an `Ok`, or `Err` with the current
 `Box<ParserState>` otherwise. If `is_positive` is `false`, it swaps the `Ok` and `Err`
 together, negating the `Result`.

attributes.value: / Starts a lookahead transformation provided by `f` from the `Box<ParserState>`. It returns
/ `Ok` with the current `Box<ParserState>` if `f` also returns an `Ok`, or `Err` with the current
/ `Box<ParserState>` otherwise. If `is_positive` is `false`, it swaps the `Ok` and `Err`
/ # #[derive(Clone, Copy, Debug, Eq, Hash, Ord, PartialEq, PartialOrd)]

defs.name: stack_push
defs.value:
fn stack_push<F>(Box<Self>, F) -> ParseResult<Box<Self>> where
F: FnOnce(Box<Self>) -> ParseResult<Box<Self>>
defs.docs:
Evaluates the result of closure `f` and pushes the span of the input consumed from before
 `f` is called to after `f` is called to the stack. Returns `Ok(Box<ParserState>)` if `f` is
 called successfully, or `Err(Box<ParserState>)` otherwise.

/ `f` is called to after `f` is called to the stack. Returns `Ok(Box<ParserState>)` if `f` is
/ # #[derive(Clone, Copy, Debug, Eq, Hash, Ord, PartialEq, PartialOrd)]

 if the string is matched successfully, or `Err(Box<ParserState>)` otherwise.

defs.name: pratt_parser
defs.docs:
Constructs useful in prefix, postfix, and infix operator parsing with the
 Pratt parsing method.

defs.name: PrattParser
defs.docs:
Struct containing operators and precedences, which can perform [Pratt parsing][1] on
 primary, prefix, postfix and infix expressions over [`Pairs`]. The tokens in [`Pairs`]
 should alternate in the order:
 `prefix* ~ primary ~ postfix* ~ (infix ~ prefix* ~ primary ~ postfix*)*`

attributes.value: / Struct containing operators and precedences, which can perform [Pratt parsing][1] on
/ primary, prefix, postfix and infix expressions over [`Pairs`]. The tokens in [`Pairs`]
/ * The tokens in `pairs` does not alternate in the expected order.
/ * No `map_*` function is specified for a certain kind of operator encountered in `pairs`.
/ The following pest grammar defines a calculator which can be used for Pratt parsing.
/   expr       =   { prefix* ~ primary ~ postfix* ~ (infix ~ prefix* ~ primary ~ postfix* )* }
/     infix    =  _{ add | sub | mul | div | pow }
/ Below is a [`PrattParser`] that is able to parse an `expr` in the above grammar. The order
/ of precedence corresponds to the order in which [`op`] is called. Thus, `mul` will
/ have higher precedence than `add`. Operators can also be chained with `|` to give them equal
/ # #[derive(Clone, Copy, Debug, Eq, Hash, Ord, PartialEq, PartialOrd)]
/ # enum Rule { program, expr, int, add, mul, sub, div, pow, fac, neg }
/ To parse an expression, call the [`map_primary`], [`map_prefix`], [`map_postfix`],
/ # #[derive(Clone, Copy, Debug, Eq, Hash, Ord, PartialEq, PartialOrd)]
/ # enum Rule { program, expr, int, add, mul, sub, div, pow, fac, neg }
/ Note that [`map_prefix`], [`map_postfix`] and [`map_infix`] only need to be specified if the

deprecated(since = "2.4.0", note =
"Use `pest::pratt_parser` instead (it is an equivalent which also supports unary prefix/suffix operators).
While prec_climber is going to be kept in 2.x minor and patch releases, it may be removed in a future major release.")

defs.name: PrecClimber
defs.docs:
List of operators and precedences, which can perform [precedence climbing][1] on infix
 expressions contained in a [`Pairs`]. The token pairs contained in the `Pairs` should start
 with a *primary* pair and then alternate between an *operator* and a *primary*.

attributes.value: / List of operators and precedences, which can perform [precedence climbing][1] on infix
/ expressions contained in a [`Pairs`]. The token pairs contained in the `Pairs` should start
/ with a *primary* pair and then alternate between an *operator* and a *primary*.

defs.name: new
defs.docs:
Creates a new `PrecClimber` from the `Operator`s contained in `ops`. Every entry in the
 `Vec` has precedence *index + 1*. In order to have operators with same precedence, they need
 to be chained with `|` between them.

attributes.value: / Creates a new `PrecClimber` from the `Operator`s contained in `ops`. Every entry in the
/ `Vec` has precedence *index + 1*. In order to have operators with same precedence, they need
/ to be chained with `|` between them.
/ # #[derive(Clone, Copy, Debug, Eq, Hash, Ord, PartialEq, PartialOrd)]

defs.name: climb
defs.value:
fn climb<'i, P, F, G, T, '_>(&'_ Self, P, F, G) -> T where P: Iterator<Item =
Pair>, F: FnMut(Pair) -> T, G: FnMut(T, Pair, T) -> T
defs.docs:
Performs the precedence climbing algorithm on the `pairs` in a similar manner to map-reduce.
 *Primary* pairs are mapped with `primary` and then reduced to one single result with
 `infix`.

defs.value: RuleType: Copy + Debug + Eq + Hash + Ord
defs.docs: A trait which parser rules must implement.

attributes.value: / A trait which parser rules must implement.
/ This trait is set up so that any struct that implements all of its required traits will
/ automatically implement this trait as well.
/ This is essentially a [trait alias](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1733). When trait
/ aliases are implemented, this may be replaced by one.
